data: PED BIOCHEM Glycogen Storage Disease (GSD) Admission
Verify that an 'Admit to' Order has been entered prior to completing the powerplan (NOT required for direct admit patient)

This patient requires limited glucose, lactose, galactose, fructose, sucrose and sorbitol. Please contact the Biochemical Genetics team if you suspect there are any of these sugars in any products provided

Patients with Glycogen Storage Disease are at risk of developing severe hypoglycemia. 
 They are totally dependent on a constant supply of dietary glucose to support their blood glucose levels.  If the child has a normal blood sugar but is unable to tolerate oral intake, an IV source of glucose needs to be provided immediately
q4h heart rate, blood pressure, respiratory rate, temperature
q2h heart rate, blood pressure, respiratory rate, temperature
q1h heart rate, blood pressure, respiratory rate, temperature
q12h heart rate, blood pressure, respiratory rate, temperature
Monitor q1h overnight and prior to meals, snacks, Glycosade and uncooked cornstarch
Monitor q1h overnight and prior to meals and snacks
RN to record amounts and time of consumption for ALL foods, fluids, Glycosade, uncooked cornstarch, and hypoglycemia rescues
RN to notify Biochemical Genetics dietitian patient is on the ward
RN to notify kitchen patient is on the ward and to bring crackers from unit kitchen/hypoglycemia kits to patient's room
GSD Diet, Oral Diet by Kitchen (Tray Service)
GSD Diet, Oral Diet by Kitchen (Tray Service)
Biochemical Genetics Glycogen Storage Disease Recipe-Based Formula
Formula Room to Prepare, Uncooked Cornstarch, grams, PO, Mix Uncooked Cornstarch with specified fluid immediately prior to administration
Formula Room to Prepare, Glycosade powder, grams, PO, Mix Glycosade with specified fluid immediately prior to administration
If requires continuous feeds provide Biochemical Genetics Carbohydrate Modified Recipe-Based Formula
Biochemical Genetics Carbohydrate Modified Recipe-Based Formula
Formula Room to Prepare, VIVONEX TEN, VIVONEX TEN 1 kcal/mL, G-Tube
Calculate Pediatric Maintenance Fluids based on 4-2-1 Rule
Contraindications:  - Lactated Ringers (can lead to acidosis)
10 mL/kg, IV, once, administer over:30 minute, drug form: bag
20 mL/kg, IV, once, administer over:30 minute, drug form: bag
10 mL/kg, IV, once, administer over:60 minute, drug form: bag
20 mL/kg, IV, once, administer over:60 minute, drug form: bag
See most recent TFI orders, IV, drug form: bag
KCL containing continuous infusions should only be started based on patient's electrolytes and renal status
See most recent TFI orders, IV, drug form: bag
See most recent TFI orders, IV, drug form: bag
See most recent TFI orders, IV, drug form: bag

Contraindications:  
- glucagon (can lead to acidosis) 
 - insulin (can lead to hypoglycemia, coma and possible death)

Avoid the following medications:  
- succinylcholine not to be used in glycogen storage disease type III, use with caution in other ketotic GSDs 
 - amoxicillin-clavulanate (will cause malabsorption of cornstarch) 
 - growth hormone causes increased ketone production
Use the following medications with caution:  cortocosteriods, beta blockers, stimulants, desmopressin
Antimicrobials accepted in GSD: azithromycin, clindamycin, cephaLEXin, trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole.  Monitoring should be performed if antimicrobials ordered

For pain management orders, including anti-emetics and antipyretics, use either the  PED Pain and Symptom Management for Age Greater than or Equal to 6 months powerplan OR PED Pain and Symptom Management for Age Less than 6 Months powerplan
Reason for Consult: Other - Per Details,Pharmacist to perform medication review to assess suitability for patient with glycogen storage disease

filgrastim usual dose range 1 to 5 mcg/kg/dose
Frequency of administration varies depending on neutrophil response - provider to modify frequency at order entry
